Question_1.Context: The study investigated the effects of different encapsulation layers on the characteristics of LIG-based pressure sensors. The fabrication process involved using various elastomers as encapsulation layers.
Question_1.Question: What was the purpose of using Si-elastomer encapsulation layers in LIG-based pressure sensors?
Question_1.A: To increase the brittleness of fabricated LIG
Question_1.B: To decrease the resistance changes in the sensors
Question_1.C: To enhance the durability of LIG against mechanical pressure
Question_1.D: To reduce the response time of the sensors
Question_1.Source: To address this durability issue, current research on LIG-based pressure sensors uses encapsulation layers. By pouring a liquid elastomer onto the LIG and subsequently applying a curing process, the elastomer can create a uniform and compact coating on the LIG, similar to a composite structure. This coating significantly enhanced the durability of LIG against mechanical pressure because the elastomer supported the LIG against mechanical pressure.

Question_2.Context: The study focused on the electromechanical characteristics of LIG-based pressure sensors encapsulated in various Si-based elastomers.
Question_2.Question: What was the effect of encapsulation layers with a lower Young’s modulus on the resistance changes and response times of the sensors?
Question_2.A: Decreased resistance changes and shorter response times
Question_2.B: Increased resistance changes and shorter response times
Question_2.C: Decreased resistance changes and extended response times
Question_2.D: Increased resistance changes and extended response times
Question_2.Source: Subsequently, the electromechanical responses of the sensors were characterized using an automated pressure machine, demonstrating that sensors with encapsulation layers with a lower Young’s modulus exhibited increased resistance changes and extended response times.

Question_3.Context: The study evaluated the environmental stability of pressure sensors with various encapsulation materials.
Question_3.Question: What was the outcome of the environmental stability tests on the pressure sensors?
Question_3.A: Significant resistance changes were observed after exposure to high temperatures.
Question_3.B: Negligible performance variations were confirmed after exposure to high temperatures.
Question_3.C: The sensors exhibited decreased sensitivity after exposure to high temperatures.
Question_3.D: The sensors showed improved durability after exposure to high temperatures.
Question_3.Source: Despite being continuously exposed to the 85 ℃ environment for 48 h, no significant resistance change was confirmed. Some minor fluctuations were observed in the data; however, these were believed to be the result of noise from the surrounding environment.

Question_4.Context: The study conducted a comprehensive electromechanical characterization of pressure sensors with different encapsulation layers.
Question_4.Question: What was the purpose of fabricating various LIG-based pressure sensors with different elastomer encapsulation layers?
Question_4.A: To compare the weight of the sensors
Question_4.B: To evaluate the performance in terms of electrical-resistance response
Question_4.C: To measure the temperature sensitivity of the sensors
Question_4.D: To assess the color variations of the sensors
Question_4.Source: Using this method, various LIG-based pressure sensors with different elastomer encapsulation layers are fabricated. Subsequently, we conduct a comprehensive electromechanical characterization of these pressure sensors using an automated pressure machine to evaluate their performance in terms of electrical-resistance response, response time, long-term reliability, and stability.

Question_5.Context: The study investigated the response times of pressure sensors with different encapsulation materials.
Question_5.Question: How did the response time of pressure sensors encapsulated with PDMS 5:1 compare to those encapsulated with PDMS 10:1, PDMS 20:1, and Ecoflex 1:1?
Question_5.A: PDMS 5:1 exhibited the longest response time
Question_5.B: PDMS 5:1 exhibited the shortest response time
Question_5.C: PDMS 5:1 and PDMS 10:1 had similar response times
Question_5.D: PDMS 5:1 and Ecoflex 1:1 had similar response times
Question_5.Source: This test confirmed that the PDMS 5:1 encapsulation material exhibited a rapid response. Specifically, at 100 kPa, the measured response times were 505 ms, 746 ms, 811 ms, and 861 ms for the devices encapsulated with PDMS 5:1, PDMS 10:1, PDMS 20:1, and Ecoflex 1:1, respectively.

Question_6.Context: The study evaluated the mechanical stability of pressure sensors with different encapsulation layers.
Question_6.Question: What was observed in the resistance changes of devices fabricated with Ecoflex and PDMS 20:1 during the repeatability test?
Question_6.B: Resistance changes decreased initially but stabilized after 1000 cycles
Question_6.C: Resistance changes remained constant throughout the test
Question_6.Source: Initially, the devices fabricated with Ecoflex and PDMS 20:1 exhibited sensitivities that were 5.3 times higher than those of devices fabricated with PDMS 5:1 and 10:1. These results can be interpreted as the result of the high applied strain owing to the low Young’s modulus. However, the resistance changes of the devices were saturated, and even after applying pressure more than 3000 times during the cyclic test, an inconspicuous degradation in the sensor performance was confirmed in all sensors.

Question_7.Context: The study conducted accelerated-degradation tests on pressure sensors with different encapsulation materials.
Question_7.Question: What was the outcome of the accelerated-degradation tests on the resistance changes of the pressure sensors?
Question_7.A: Significant degradation in resistance changes was observed after exposure to high temperatures
Question_7.B: No significant degradation in resistance changes was observed after exposure to high temperatures
Question_7.C: Resistance changes increased consistently after exposure to high temperatures
Question_7.D: Resistance changes fluctuated randomly after exposure to high temperatures
Question_7.Source: Despite being continuously exposed to the 85 ℃ environment for 48 h, no significant resistance change was confirmed. Some minor fluctuations were observed in the data; however, these were believed to be the result of noise from the surrounding environment.

Question_8.Context: The study focused on the effects of different encapsulation layers on the characteristics of LIG-based pressure sensors.
Question_8.Question: What was the purpose of conducting tensile tests on the dog-bone model structures of different elastomers?
Question_8.A: To measure the electrical resistance of the sensors
Question_8.B: To evaluate the mechanical properties and Young’s moduli of the elastomers
Question_8.C: To assess the response time of the sensors
Question_8.D: To compare the weight of the sensors
Question_8.Source: To confirm the Young’s moduli of the encapsulation-layer materials, we fabricated dog-bone model structures for each elastomer and conducted tensile tests using a force gauge. Stress-strain curves were plotted for the dog-bone structures of PDMS 5:1, PDMS 10:1, PDMS 20:1, and Ecoflex 1:1 using the force gauge, and the Young’s moduli were measured.

Question_9.Context: The study evaluated the electromechanical characteristics of LIG-based pressure sensors with different encapsulation layers.
Question_9.Question: What was the observed trend in the response time of pressure sensors as the applied pressure increased?
Question_9.A: Response time decreased as the applied pressure increased
Question_9.B: Response time remained constant regardless of the applied pressure
Question_9.C: Response time increased as the applied pressure increased
Question_9.D: Response time fluctuated randomly with changes in the applied pressure
Question_9.Source: This test confirmed that the PDMS 5:1 encapsulation material exhibited a rapid response. Specifically, at 100 kPa, the measured response times were 505 ms, 746 ms, 811 ms, and 861 ms for the devices encapsulated with PDMS 5:1, PDMS 10:1, PDMS 20:1, and Ecoflex 1:1, respectively. We also attribute this response-time trend to the Young’s modulus of the encapsulation material.

Question_10.Context: The study investigated the effects of different encapsulation layers on the characteristics of LIG-based pressure sensors.
Question_10.Question: What was the conclusion regarding the stabilities of LIG-based pressure sensors with different encapsulation layers?
Question_10.A: The stabilities were significantly compromised after exposure to high temperatures
Question_10.B: The stabilities were not significantly compromised even when a flexible material was used
Question_10.C: The stabilities were improved after exposure to high temperatures
Question_10.D: The stabilities fluctuated depending on the encapsulation material
Question_10.Source: Through repeated cycling and accelerated-degradation tests, we confirmed that the stabilities of the LIG-based pressure sensors with the encapsulation layers were not significantly compromised, even when a flexible material was used.
